translations.translation: Look out, the snake may bite you.
Your dog did not bite me.

sentences.transcription: murra walgaani buka yanhthabarra gigaanha manhdharra

translations.translation: Now all of you women go out to fetch bullrushes.
I give back your meat to you.

sentences.transcription: ngutyalha ngathu inha bakarranyi/ yundru nganha ngutyadhikarri nguthi

translations.translation: When/if I give back the boomerang, you will give me back the meat.

notes: bare verb = IMP; dhika = some kind of directional meaning 'back/away' used with imperatives?

translations.translation: This dog is sick (and) it will die, I think.
This dog will die, I think.

notes: noise or ear? deaf often =earless in Ab'l lanugages
'deaf' words are often 'ear-priv' in the languages of the region. ngara is also recorded as "hear".
note that adj has NOM case and occurs before the noun this time (contrast with other sentences--'My dog is good/bad')

translations.translation: The mob of men (together) are strong.
The two of you eat this food.
The water is to the left, you will go. (To the water left, you will go.)
The water is to the right, you will go. (To the water right, you will go.)
Wait, I will tell you straight.

notes: Not sure if this also has the -wari 'vertical' suffix on it, and dhuna is not correctly glossed.
Note another adverb going directly after the vern.

translations.translation: He didn't eat any food today.
This man is angry with me.
Why is that man angry with me?
That's why he is angry with you.

sentences.transcription: murrawali nganyi wagarra/ galgurigala nganyi mugaanga

translations.translation: All right, I will lie down, I am tired [for sleep].
Two big men are coming this way [returning?].
Two small men are coming this way.

notes: tense - should this be 'I will stand up' since -ra marks future?

translations.translation: The two of you stand up.

notes: Note verb with tense marking comes first ("speak-pres you Galali")
example - response to basic introduction question (Do you speak Galali?)
example - response to basic introduction question (Do you speak Galali?)

translations.translation: Yes well, completely I understand them. [OK, I understand them.]
Speak to the two of us.
Good, I will speak to you.
OK, the two of us will speak to you.
Good, we will all speak to you.
Come on, we will talk to that one over there.
